name: Starbucks
overviewText:
Starbucks provides abundant information about ingredients for all of their products. They are also clear on their website that they cannot guarantee that there will not be cross-contact of any allergen in their drinks and food. Each manager we surveyed echoed this and explained that shared equipment is used to prepare all their items. The managers expressed a willingness to instruct their staff to wash their hands, wash the pitchers, and use clean utensils when preparing a critical dietary restriction order.

Managers did tell us that ordering an iced drink has less of a chance for cross-contact since all components are poured directly into the cup.

name: Chipotle Mexican Grill
overviewText:
Chipotle stands out for having a menu that is free of several top allergens. No peanuts, tree nuts, sesame, shellfish, or fish are used as food ingredients. Eggs are only an ingredient at locations that serve breakfast and only one menu item contains soy. Their allergen and special diets menu is very easy to use and understand and has excellent notes for added detail about ingredients. In addition to the top 8 allergens and gluten, Chipotle provides information for mustard and sulfites, as well as for those following a vegetarian, vegan, whole30, keto, or paleo diet.

Chipotle is happy to accomodate guests with critical dietary restrictions and looks to the customer for direction on any special handling they would like for their order. Upon request, gloves are changed and hands are washed. Unopened bins or unused product from the back can be used upon request for any guests concerned about cross-contact. You may request one staff member make your order, instead of passing it down the line. All items on the line have dedicated spoons/utensils so that cross-contact risk is reduced. The order is prepared right in front of you so you know everything that goes into it and can feel comfortable with the process. All locations are owned by the corporation so training, process, and ingredients are consistent. One negative is that there is no place to enter critical dietary restriction information when ordering online or through their app. Guests need to either call the location or visit in-person to communicate any critical dietary restriction needs.

name: Five Guys
overviewText:
Five Guys has an excellent allergen menu that includes cross-contact risks , sesame listings, and full ingredients for some items. Additionally, their items are made to order and guests can watch their order as it is made. Because of the robust allergen menu and made-to-order meals, Five Guys is a great restaurant for several dietary restrictions.

In our surveys, each location was consistent in their critical dietary restriction awareness and process. However, it would be nice if they had dedicated utensils for each burger topping, clearer protocol for cleaning the blender for critical dietary restriction orders, and a gluten-free bun for celiac and gluten sensitivity.

Because they get ingredients with a gloved hand, you'll need to ask them to pull your ingredients from fresh bins, which they have told us they are happy to do. If you get a milkshake, ask that they use fresh sanitizing wash to clean it really well before blending your shake.

One grill is used for cooking meat (contains dairy and hydrolyzed soy protein ingredients) and the other grill is used for wheat products (contains soy, sesame, dairy and egg-ingredients). The only items in the fryer are refined peanut oil and french fries. Other than 100% refined peanut oil, the fryer is free of gluten and all of the other top 8 allergens.

name: Del Taco
overviewText: Their dietary restriction menu contains information for the top 8 allergens, gluten, and vegan/vegetarian, and they have certainly given thought to serving those with vegetarian and vegan diets. Some locations reviewed by Picknic were more knowledgeable of critical dietary restrictions and willing to accomodate than others, but all locations offered to use fresh utensils and change gloves before preparing food for a critical dietary restriction.

name: Denny's
overviewText:
Most managers at Denny's that were contacted by Picknic were familiar with critical dietary restrictions and understand general procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions; however, there were some locations that lacked adequate knowledge regarding celiac disease and the risks of cross-contact with gluten in their kitchens.

There are three separate grill spaces. One cooks fish and chicken, the second cooks red meats and the third grill cooks pancakes, French toast and eggs. Dairy (butter) is used on all grills. The managers contacted by Picknic could not ensure that their grills were completely free of allergens. A few locations were willing to utilize new utensils, clean the grill and/or use pans to prepare foods for those with critical dietary restrictions, but it must be requested by the customer.

There are three fryers used. One fries fish and chicken and has cross-contact with fish, wheat, and egg. The second cooks breaded items like onion rings and has cross-contact with wheat and egg. The third fries cheese sticks and has cross-contact with dairy, wheat, and egg.

Denny’s has an informative allergen menu that designates if an item contains or may contain an allergen. There is also cross-contact information on the allergen menu and indicates if the item is processed in a facility or on equipment with an allergen. There is a further breakdown of information about tree nuts (almonds, coconut, hazelnut) and fish (anchovies, cod/pollock/white fish, salmon).

In summary, they have a wide menu, willingness to accommodate dietary restrictions, and an online allergen guide. However, their knowledge of critical dietary restrictions varied between locations and the restaurant chain does not have consistent procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions in the restaurants.

name: Sonic Drive-In
categories: Burger, Fast Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
overviewText: We give Sonic kudos for having a robust allergen menu. However, employee training and process for avoiding cross-contact is lacking. Therefore experiences at Sonic will be inconsistent. At one location we were informed that "our entire menu is gluten-free," which is not the case. We don't recommend Sonic for people with Critical Dietary Restrictions such as food allergies and celiac disease. However, their fries and tots are fried in a separate fryer, so they should truly be gluten-free.

name: In-N-Out Burger
overviewText:
In-N-Out has a very simple menu and has the ability to serve a variety of dietary restrictions.

The fries are the only items that go in the fryers. Each griddle has two sides that do not touch due to a metal divider in between. The burger patties are cooked on one side and the buns are toasted on the other, but spatulas are not dedicated to each side. Cheese is added to burger patties while they are on the griddle, which creates a cross-contact risk on the griddle for dairy and soy.

Toppings for burgers are pulled from bins with gloved hands, which presents a risk of cross-contact if someone touches cheese, for example, and then reaches into the lettuce bin. Locations may be willing and able to pull toppings from fresh bins.

Shakes are premixed, not blended in a blender, and come straight out of a dispenser into the cup. Each shake flavor has its own dedicated tube and these are not rotated, which reduces the risk of cross-contact for shakes.

name: Domino's
overviewText:
Domino's has an online allergen guide posted for those with critical dietary restrictions to help customers navigate the menu.

The locations reviewed by Picknic were consistent in their procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions and were fairly knowledgeable of a variety of food allergies. They strive to be as accommodating as possible but their toppings bar, which contains meat, dairy, and fish products, is used for all pizzas and can be a risk for cross-contact for customers with those critical dietary restrictions. The staff change their gloves and prepares the pizzas on individual screens to reduce these risks but they cannot guarantee their foods are 100% free of those allergens. Additionally, they do not have separate ovens for different allergens so those with a gluten critical dietary restriction should be aware that their gluten-free pizza may come into contact with gluten-containing items in the oven or on the toppings bar. Some restaurants use stickers to identify gluten-free pizzas that they place on their boxes.

Overall, Domino's has standardized procedures and a good understanding of critical dietary restrictions.

name: Baskin-Robbins
categories: Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Donuts
overviewText:
All ice cream flavors are manufactured in the same facility. If you are comfortable with that, Baskin-Robbins should be a good option for you. Just be sure to ask the staff to wash their hands and get your ice cream from a fresh bin with fresh utensils. Otherwise, cross-contact is highly likely since the scoops used for ice cream and the wells for the scoops are shared. Toppings (including peanuts and tree nuts) are typically stored close together on the line, so there is an elevated risk of cross-contact between toppings.

The waffle cones offered are prepared in-house every day, whereas the sugar and cake cones are shipped from a factory. The waffle cones contain multiple allergens, including gluten, wheat, soy, eggs, and milk. The waffle irons are located in a separate area from the ice cream tubs and are produced in the morning to reduce risk of cross-contact.

Their online menu provides an easy-to-use filter to help customers navigate the menu according to their dietary restrictions or preferences, but not every flavor listed online is offered at every location.

The managers contacted by Picknic showed little knowledge regarding food allergies so you will need to be your own advocate. The procedures for accommodating critical dietary restrictions were not standardized across the reviewed facilities. There were discrepancies in the understanding of company policies and procedures; some locations did not require their employees to wear gloves when scooping ice cream, whereas other locations did require gloves.

name: Chick-fil-A
overviewText:
Chick-Fil-A has a comprehensive allergen menu, the ability to print a list of all ingredients in an item for guests, and an excellent level of management training/customer service. Additionally, their willingness to change gloves, use fresh utensils, and make other accommodations is an outlier in the fast food industry.

That being said, it is possible that some locations will fall short of the general Chik-Fil-A standard. For orders that require special handling, we recommend placing your order in-store so that you can speak directly to an employee.

name: Jamba Juice
overviewText:
Jamba Juice's online menu lists the ingredients used in each of their menu items and make special note of certain allergens present in their food, including dairy, soy, tree nuts (almond and coconut), wheat, and egg. The smoothies and juices at Jamba Juice allow for some modifications, if necessary, to accomodate for critical dietary restrictions.

The staff reviewed by Picknic gave consistent responses regarding their procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions and happily answered any questions regarding their menu items and the allergens at their location.

Picknic believes Jamba Juice is a good option for those with gluten, egg, and wheat critical dietary restrictions because there are few or no blended menu items that contain these allergens. The foods offered that contain wheat, gluten, and egg are specific to their breakfast items, flatbreads, and baked goods which are manufactured and individually packaged outside of the restaurant, stored in a separate refrigerator from their smoothie and juice ingredients, and cooked in an oven that is typically in a separate area from the blenders. Jamba Juice stores do not carry any fish or shellfish products.

Although there are menu items that are free of peanuts, tree nuts, dairy, and soy, there is an elevated risk risk of cross-contact for these ingredients due to shared blenders.

name: Buca di Beppo Italian Restaurant
overviewText:
Although Buca di Beppo's menu is not very flexible for all critical dietary restrictions, some managers surveyed by Picknic were very willing to accommodate as much as possible. The restaurant chain serves family-style meals but some locations said they would be willing to prepare individual-sized portions for someone with a critical dietary restriction.

Buca di Beppo displays consistent willingness to accommodate as much as possible for customers with critical dietary restrictions. However, Picknic does not recommend this restaurant chain for every allergy because the majority of their menu items contain multiple allergens and cannot be modified to remove them. They have a complete allergen menu available online but each manager reviewed by Picknic was also willing to answer questions regarding critical dietary restrictions.

The restaurant has two fryers, both of which are used for wheat, dairy, egg, fish, shellfish, and soy containing items.

name: Red Robin Gourmet Burgers and Brews
overviewText:
Red Robin provides an interactive allergen menu that includes the top 8 allergens, gluten-free, and vegan options. This menu allows the user to filter by critical dietary restriction. The output shows what items do not contain your restricted ingredients and highlights where cross-contact is possible. It also tells you how to modify certain menu items to meet your needs. The company provides further transparency on the FAQ section of their website, where additional information about cross-contact, staff training, and standard critical dietary restriction procedures is outlined. 

Managers surveyed were knowledgeable about critical dietary restrictions and their answers about their critical dietary restriction process were consistent with what was outlined on the corporate website. Red Robin is rated as a Picknic Pick for all of the top 8 allergens, gluten-free, and vegan critical dietary restrictions due the chain's high level of transparency on ingredients and cross-contact, staff training, and the policies in place to safely handle critical dietary restriction orders.

name: California Pizza Kitchen
overviewText:
California Pizza Kitchen seems committed to serving people with critical dietary restrictions such as celiac disease and food allergies.

There is an elevated risk of cross-contact with many allergens due to the nature of how the prep stations are set up. The only menu items that CPK will guarantee to not have cross-contact are their certified gluten-free items. For these items, they guarantee there is not cross-contact with gluten.

Vegetarians and vegans will delight in reading the CPK Vegetarian and Vegan Menu Guide. This guide clearly outlines all the foods that are either naturally vegetarian or vegan or can be modified to become vegetarian or vegan.

name: Blaze Fast-Fire’d Pizza
overviewText:
Blaze Pizza offers different pizzas to cater to people with different critical dietary restrictions. There are a few choices for dough ranging from wheat, gluten-free, cauliflower and keto. Blaze uses Daiya dairy-free cheese, offers a vegan chorizo topping, and has a large variety of meats and vegetable toppings. Regardless of your critical dietary restriction, building your own pizza is a good choice.

All pizzas are cooked in the same oven, however when we asked if there is a special place in the oven for critical dietary restriction pizzas we received different answers. Some said they use the far side of the oven for critical dietary restrictions, others surveyed said all pizzas go in the oven in no particular place.

Blaze Pizza has a Special Diets Wizard (allergen menu) online powered by nutritionix and lists 24 allergens giving you the option to choose what you wish to avoid. Once the items are selected, you will see the items that do contain your allergens and that do not contain your allergens.

It’s not easy to find the phone number to your local Blaze Pizza. Once you find your location on the website, click that location on the map view to get the phone number, address, and hours of operation.

name: Cold Stone Creamery
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Cupcakes, Custom Cakes
overviewText:
Cold Stone Creamery has a willingness to accommodate critical dietary restriction orders. They have standardized procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions. Locations reviewed by Picknic offered to scoop from fresh, unused ice cream tubs in the back of the house using fresh utensils for all critical dietary restrictions. This is a corporate policy and was upheld for all reviewed locations. Additionally, the staff will use clean cambro bins in the back to mix any ice cream orders for critical dietary restrictions to reduce the risk of cross-contact.

The set up of ice cream, toppings/add-ins, and cones can vary by location. Ice cream and sorbets are in individual bins and generally set up side by side in two rows. The order of the toppings can vary depending on the location. Some stores may put cookie/brownie toppings, tree nuts, and peanuts in the middle, and others may put them off to the side. Toppings are stored in individual covered containers and have their own scoop. The topping station is next to the ice cream station where there are cones and waffle cups above the toppings.

Ice creams, sorbets, and mix-ins are produced off-site. Picknic was unable to obtain information about Cold Stone Creamery's manufacturing process, so cross-contact in manufacturing may be possible.

Jamba Juice stores do not carry any fish or shellfish products.

Although there are menu items that are free of peanuts, tree nuts, dairy, and soy, there is an elevated risk risk of cross-contact for these ingredients due to shared blenders.

The managers expressed a willingness to instruct their staff to wash their hands, wash the pitchers, and use clean utensils when preparing a critical dietary restriction order.

name: Sonic Drive-In
categories: Burger, Fast Food, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt
overviewText: We give Sonic kudos for having a robust allergen menu. However, employee training and process for avoiding cross-contact is lacking. Therefore experiences at Sonic will be inconsistent. At one location we were informed that "our entire menu is gluten-free," which is not the case. We don't recommend Sonic for people with Critical Dietary Restrictions such as food allergies and celiac disease. However, their fries and tots are fried in a separate fryer, so they should truly be gluten-free.

name: Olive Garden Italian Kitchen
overviewText: Olive Garden impresses with transparent information about its menu items and operations that will allow those with critical dietary restrictions to make informed choices. Olive Garden’s website offers information for those avoiding the top 8 allergens, gluten, sesame, and sulfites. Their allergen guide also includes information on preparation methods and possible cross-contact. A menu detailing vegetarian and vegan options is also available on their website. In Picknic surveys, managers were knowledgeable about ingredients and procedures and were happy to accomodate guests with critical dietary restrictions.

name: Chuck E. Cheese
overviewText: Chuck-E-Cheese offers an allergen menu with the top 8 allergens plus gluten as well as additional information in the food allergy FAQs on their webpage. In our surveys, we found inconsistent levels of knowledge and training regarding critical dietary restrictions. Some managers were well-trained and appeared to have a consistent process for handling critical dietary restriction orders while others did not. Pizzas are assembled in the kitchen and cooked on trays that go through a conveyor-type oven. All other food items are cooked on trays that go through the same conveyor oven. Since all food items are cooked separately on trays it presents a reduced risk of cross-contact from shared cooking surfaces. Cross-contact is possible in the preparation spaces, particularly with wheat, gluten, dairy or soy.

name: Chick-fil-A
overviewText:
Chick-Fil-A has a comprehensive allergen menu, the ability to print a list of all ingredients in an item for guests, and an excellent level of management training/customer service. Additionally, their willingness to change gloves, use fresh utensils, and make other accommodations is an outlier in the fast food industry.

That being said, it is possible that some locations will fall short of the general Chik-Fil-A standard. For orders that require special handling, we recommend placing your order in-store so that you can speak directly to an employee.

name: Five Guys
overviewText:
Five Guys has an excellent allergen menu that includes cross-contact risks , sesame listings, and full ingredients for some items. Additionally, their items are made to order and guests can watch their order as it is made. Because of the robust allergen menu and made-to-order meals, Five Guys is a great restaurant for several dietary restrictions.

In our surveys, each location was consistent in their critical dietary restriction awareness and process. However, it would be nice if they had dedicated utensils for each burger topping, clearer protocol for cleaning the blender for critical dietary restriction orders, and a gluten-free bun for celiac and gluten sensitivity.

Because they get ingredients with a gloved hand, you'll need to ask them to pull your ingredients from fresh bins, which they have told us they are happy to do. If you get a milkshake, ask that they use fresh sanitizing wash to clean it really well before blending your shake.

One grill is used for cooking meat (contains dairy and hydrolyzed soy protein ingredients) and the other grill is used for wheat products (contains soy, sesame, dairy and egg-ingredients). The only items in the fryer are refined peanut oil and french fries. Other than 100% refined peanut oil, the fryer is free of gluten and all of the other top 8 allergens.

name: Pei Wei
overviewText:
Pei Wei is committed to serving guests with critical dietary restrictions such as food allergies and celiac disease. Their layout and operations reflect this commitment. Many locations discuss food allergies and celiac disease daily to be sure everyone is on the same page.

They will make any meal with any protein or sauce. They can add extra vegetables or remove ingredients upon request. Gluten-free soy sauce is also available.

In the beginning of the day many proteins are dipped in egg during the preparation process. In order to prepare your meal without egg, call the day before and speak to a manager. Request that the next day your protein of choice is set aside before adding the egg wash. Willingness to accommodate will vary depending on the location.

Some of the restaurants we surveyed were not as educated about their food ingredients and conditions such as celiac disease as we would like. However, their process and protocol are consistent.

name: Blaze Fast-Fire’d Pizza
overviewText:
Blaze Pizza offers different pizzas to cater to people with different critical dietary restrictions. There are a few choices for dough ranging from wheat, gluten-free, cauliflower and keto. Blaze uses Daiya dairy-free cheese, offers a vegan chorizo topping, and has a large variety of meats and vegetable toppings. Regardless of your critical dietary restriction, building your own pizza is a good choice.

All pizzas are cooked in the same oven, however when we asked if there is a special place in the oven for critical dietary restriction pizzas we received different answers. Some said they use the far side of the oven for critical dietary restrictions, others surveyed said all pizzas go in the oven in no particular place.

Blaze Pizza has a Special Diets Wizard (allergen menu) online powered by nutritionix and lists 24 allergens giving you the option to choose what you wish to avoid. Once the items are selected, you will see the items that do contain your allergens and that do not contain your allergens.

It’s not easy to find the phone number to your local Blaze Pizza. Once you find your location on the website, click that location on the map view to get the phone number, address, and hours of operation.

name: Cold Stone Creamery
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Cupcakes, Custom Cakes
overviewText:
Cold Stone Creamery has a willingness to accommodate critical dietary restriction orders. They have standardized procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions. Locations reviewed by Picknic offered to scoop from fresh, unused ice cream tubs in the back of the house using fresh utensils for all critical dietary restrictions. This is a corporate policy and was upheld for all reviewed locations. Additionally, the staff will use clean cambro bins in the back to mix any ice cream orders for critical dietary restrictions to reduce the risk of cross-contact.

The set up of ice cream, toppings/add-ins, and cones can vary by location. Ice cream and sorbets are in individual bins and generally set up side by side in two rows. The order of the toppings can vary depending on the location. Some stores may put cookie/brownie toppings, tree nuts, and peanuts in the middle, and others may put them off to the side. Toppings are stored in individual covered containers and have their own scoop. The topping station is next to the ice cream station where there are cones and waffle cups above the toppings.

Ice creams, sorbets, and mix-ins are produced off-site. Picknic was unable to obtain information about Cold Stone Creamery's manufacturing process, so cross-contact in manufacturing may be possible.

name: In-N-Out Burger
overviewText:
In-N-Out has a very simple menu and has the ability to serve a variety of dietary restrictions.

The fries are the only items that go in the fryers. Each griddle has two sides that do not touch due to a metal divider in between. The burger patties are cooked on one side and the buns are toasted on the other, but spatulas are not dedicated to each side. Cheese is added to burger patties while they are on the griddle, which creates a cross-contact risk on the griddle for dairy and soy.

Toppings for burgers are pulled from bins with gloved hands, which presents a risk of cross-contact if someone touches cheese, for example, and then reaches into the lettuce bin. Locations may be willing and able to pull toppings from fresh bins.

Shakes are premixed, not blended in a blender, and come straight out of a dispenser into the cup. Each shake flavor has its own dedicated tube and these are not rotated, which reduces the risk of cross-contact for shakes.

name: Denny's
overviewText:
Most managers at Denny's that were contacted by Picknic were familiar with critical dietary restrictions and understand general procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions; however, there were some locations that lacked adequate knowledge regarding celiac disease and the risks of cross-contact with gluten in their kitchens.

There are three separate grill spaces. One cooks fish and chicken, the second cooks red meats and the third grill cooks pancakes, French toast and eggs. Dairy (butter) is used on all grills. The managers contacted by Picknic could not ensure that their grills were completely free of allergens. A few locations were willing to utilize new utensils, clean the grill and/or use pans to prepare foods for those with critical dietary restrictions, but it must be requested by the customer.

There are three fryers used. One fries fish and chicken and has cross-contact with fish, wheat, and egg. The second cooks breaded items like onion rings and has cross-contact with wheat and egg. The third fries cheese sticks and has cross-contact with dairy, wheat, and egg.

Denny’s has an informative allergen menu that designates if an item contains or may contain an allergen. There is also cross-contact information on the allergen menu and indicates if the item is processed in a facility or on equipment with an allergen. There is a further breakdown of information about tree nuts (almonds, coconut, hazelnut) and fish (anchovies, cod/pollock/white fish, salmon).

In summary, they have a wide menu, willingness to accommodate dietary restrictions, and an online allergen guide. However, their knowledge of critical dietary restrictions varied between locations and the restaurant chain does not have consistent procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions in the restaurants.

name: Chipotle Mexican Grill
overviewText:
Chipotle stands out for having a menu that is free of several top allergens. No peanuts, tree nuts, sesame, shellfish, or fish are used as food ingredients. Eggs are only an ingredient at locations that serve breakfast and only one menu item contains soy. Their allergen and special diets menu is very easy to use and understand and has excellent notes for added detail about ingredients. In addition to the top 8 allergens and gluten, Chipotle provides information for mustard and sulfites, as well as for those following a vegetarian, vegan, whole30, keto, or paleo diet.

Chipotle is happy to accomodate guests with critical dietary restrictions and looks to the customer for direction on any special handling they would like for their order. Upon request, gloves are changed and hands are washed. Unopened bins or unused product from the back can be used upon request for any guests concerned about cross-contact. You may request one staff member make your order, instead of passing it down the line. All items on the line have dedicated spoons/utensils so that cross-contact risk is reduced. The order is prepared right in front of you so you know everything that goes into it and can feel comfortable with the process. All locations are owned by the corporation so training, process, and ingredients are consistent. One negative is that there is no place to enter critical dietary restriction information when ordering online or through their app. Guests need to either call the location or visit in-person to communicate any critical dietary restriction needs.

name: Starbucks
overviewText:
Starbucks provides abundant information about ingredients for all of their products. They are also clear on their website that they cannot guarantee that there will not be cross-contact of any allergen in their drinks and food. Each manager we surveyed echoed this and explained that shared equipment is used to prepare all their items. The managers expressed a willingness to instruct their staff to wash their hands, wash the pitchers, and use clean utensils when preparing a critical dietary restriction order.

Managers did tell us that ordering an iced drink has less of a chance for cross-contact since all components are poured directly into the cup.

name: Baskin-Robbins
categories: Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Donuts
overviewText:
All ice cream flavors are manufactured in the same facility. If you are comfortable with that, Baskin-Robbins should be a good option for you. Just be sure to ask the staff to wash their hands and get your ice cream from a fresh bin with fresh utensils. Otherwise, cross-contact is highly likely since the scoops used for ice cream and the wells for the scoops are shared. Toppings (including peanuts and tree nuts) are typically stored close together on the line, so there is an elevated risk of cross-contact between toppings.

The waffle cones offered are prepared in-house every day, whereas the sugar and cake cones are shipped from a factory. The waffle cones contain multiple allergens, including gluten, wheat, soy, eggs, and milk. The waffle irons are located in a separate area from the ice cream tubs and are produced in the morning to reduce risk of cross-contact.

Their online menu provides an easy-to-use filter to help customers navigate the menu according to their dietary restrictions or preferences, but not every flavor listed online is offered at every location.

The managers contacted by Picknic showed little knowledge regarding food allergies so you will need to be your own advocate. The procedures for accommodating critical dietary restrictions were not standardized across the reviewed facilities. There were discrepancies in the understanding of company policies and procedures; some locations did not require their employees to wear gloves when scooping ice cream, whereas other locations did require gloves.

name: Applebee’s Grill + Bar
overviewText: Though Applebee's provides an allergen menu, staff (including management) at locations we surveyed did not know the menu and potential sources of cross-contact well enough to guide guests. However, because of the lack of peanuts on their menu, Applebee's is a Picknic Pick for peanut-free.

name: Domino's
overviewText:
Domino's has an online allergen guide posted for those with critical dietary restrictions to help customers navigate the menu.

The locations reviewed by Picknic were consistent in their procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions and were fairly knowledgeable of a variety of food allergies. They strive to be as accommodating as possible but their toppings bar, which contains meat, dairy, and fish products, is used for all pizzas and can be a risk for cross-contact for customers with those critical dietary restrictions. The staff change their gloves and prepares the pizzas on individual screens to reduce these risks but they cannot guarantee their foods are 100% free of those allergens. Additionally, they do not have separate ovens for different allergens so those with a gluten critical dietary restriction should be aware that their gluten-free pizza may come into contact with gluten-containing items in the oven or on the toppings bar. Some restaurants use stickers to identify gluten-free pizzas that they place on their boxes.

Overall, Domino's has standardized procedures and a good understanding of critical dietary restrictions.

overviewText:

The responses regarding allergens present in their menu items varied between locations, despite the availability of an online allergen guide.

The food items at Dunkin' Donuts are all shipped in from a manufacturing facility so their products may contain or come in contact with gluten, eggs, milk, soy, peanuts, tree nuts, fish, shellfish, or wheat. At the restaurant locations, the food items are reheated in shared ovens.

name: Starbucks
overviewText:
Starbucks provides abundant information about ingredients for all of their products. They are also clear on their website that they cannot guarantee that there will not be cross-contact of any allergen in their drinks and food. Each manager we surveyed echoed this and explained that shared equipment is used to prepare all their items. The managers expressed a willingness to instruct their staff to wash their hands, wash the pitchers, and use clean utensils when preparing a critical dietary restriction order.

Managers did tell us that ordering an iced drink has less of a chance for cross-contact since all components are poured directly into the cup.

name: Domino's
overviewText:
Domino's has an online allergen guide posted for those with critical dietary restrictions to help customers navigate the menu.

The locations reviewed by Picknic were consistent in their procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions and were fairly knowledgeable of a variety of food allergies. They strive to be as accommodating as possible but their toppings bar, which contains meat, dairy, and fish products, is used for all pizzas and can be a risk for cross-contact for customers with those critical dietary restrictions. The staff change their gloves and prepares the pizzas on individual screens to reduce these risks but they cannot guarantee their foods are 100% free of those allergens. Additionally, they do not have separate ovens for different allergens so those with a gluten critical dietary restriction should be aware that their gluten-free pizza may come into contact with gluten-containing items in the oven or on the toppings bar. Some restaurants use stickers to identify gluten-free pizzas that they place on their boxes.

Overall, Domino's has standardized procedures and a good understanding of critical dietary restrictions.

name: Baskin-Robbins
categories: Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Donuts
overviewText:
All ice cream flavors are manufactured in the same facility. If you are comfortable with that, Baskin-Robbins should be a good option for you. Just be sure to ask the staff to wash their hands and get your ice cream from a fresh bin with fresh utensils. Otherwise, cross-contact is highly likely since the scoops used for ice cream and the wells for the scoops are shared. Toppings (including peanuts and tree nuts) are typically stored close together on the line, so there is an elevated risk of cross-contact between toppings.

The waffle cones offered are prepared in-house every day, whereas the sugar and cake cones are shipped from a factory. The waffle cones contain multiple allergens, including gluten, wheat, soy, eggs, and milk. The waffle irons are located in a separate area from the ice cream tubs and are produced in the morning to reduce risk of cross-contact.

Their online menu provides an easy-to-use filter to help customers navigate the menu according to their dietary restrictions or preferences, but not every flavor listed online is offered at every location.

The managers contacted by Picknic showed little knowledge regarding food allergies so you will need to be your own advocate. The procedures for accommodating critical dietary restrictions were not standardized across the reviewed facilities. There were discrepancies in the understanding of company policies and procedures; some locations did not require their employees to wear gloves when scooping ice cream, whereas other locations did require gloves.

name: Chili's Grill and Bar
overviewText:
Chili's extensive menu allows for many people with critical dietary restrictions to find food options suitable for them. For those with allergies, the staff is willing to accommodate as best they can by omitting ingredients accordingly and using fresh utensils when preparing the food.

It is important to inform your server of your food allergy immediately or make note of the allergy when ordering online. Some locations offer the option to have the critical dietary restriction-friendly meal brought to table on a separate tray from other prepared foods. Managers of the restaurants reviewed by Picknic highlighted the routine hand washing and changing of gloves by the kitchen staff, especially when preparing meals for critical dietary restrictions. The managers are trained on how to handle food allergies.

Each establishment is provided with resources for both staff and customers to determine what foods can be made or adjusted to fit critical dietary restrictions. As a whole, Chili's managers contacted by Picknic were quick to respond to questions and offer helpful information regarding their procedures and offer ways they could accomodate for a variety of food allergies. However, understanding of food allergies was occasionally inconsistent among the managers we surveyed.

Chili’s has a complex Allergen/Vegetarian/Vegan Matrix which designates cross-contact and the Top 8 Allergens in every item in addition to those dishes which are vegetarian and Vegan.

All of their fried foods are made in the same fryer so there are cross-contact risks for all food allergies with their fried menu items. All fish and shellfish food items are cooked in designated pans to reduce the risk of cross-contact with other food items. The fryer oil used varied amongst the restaurants contacted by Picknic but most of the locations used either soybean oil or vegetable oil (most likely soybean oil). The oil used on the flat top grills contained soy at most locations so it is important for customers with a soy allergy to discuss their allergy with a manager before ordering.

name: Domino's
overviewText:
Domino's has an online allergen guide posted for those with critical dietary restrictions to help customers navigate the menu.

The locations reviewed by Picknic were consistent in their procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions and were fairly knowledgeable of a variety of food allergies. They strive to be as accommodating as possible but their toppings bar, which contains meat, dairy, and fish products, is used for all pizzas and can be a risk for cross-contact for customers with those critical dietary restrictions. The staff change their gloves and prepares the pizzas on individual screens to reduce these risks but they cannot guarantee their foods are 100% free of those allergens. Additionally, they do not have separate ovens for different allergens so those with a gluten critical dietary restriction should be aware that their gluten-free pizza may come into contact with gluten-containing items in the oven or on the toppings bar. Some restaurants use stickers to identify gluten-free pizzas that they place on their boxes.

Overall, Domino's has standardized procedures and a good understanding of critical dietary restrictions.

name: In-N-Out Burger
overviewText:
In-N-Out has a very simple menu and has the ability to serve a variety of dietary restrictions.

The fries are the only items that go in the fryers. Each griddle has two sides that do not touch due to a metal divider in between. The burger patties are cooked on one side and the buns are toasted on the other, but spatulas are not dedicated to each side. Cheese is added to burger patties while they are on the griddle, which creates a cross-contact risk on the griddle for dairy and soy.

Toppings for burgers are pulled from bins with gloved hands, which presents a risk of cross-contact if someone touches cheese, for example, and then reaches into the lettuce bin. Locations may be willing and able to pull toppings from fresh bins.

Shakes are premixed, not blended in a blender, and come straight out of a dispenser into the cup. Each shake flavor has its own dedicated tube and these are not rotated, which reduces the risk of cross-contact for shakes.

name: Blaze Fast-Fire’d Pizza
overviewText:
Blaze Pizza offers different pizzas to cater to people with different critical dietary restrictions. There are a few choices for dough ranging from wheat, gluten-free, cauliflower and keto. Blaze uses Daiya dairy-free cheese, offers a vegan chorizo topping, and has a large variety of meats and vegetable toppings. Regardless of your critical dietary restriction, building your own pizza is a good choice.

All pizzas are cooked in the same oven, however when we asked if there is a special place in the oven for critical dietary restriction pizzas we received different answers. Some said they use the far side of the oven for critical dietary restrictions, others surveyed said all pizzas go in the oven in no particular place.

Blaze Pizza has a Special Diets Wizard (allergen menu) online powered by nutritionix and lists 24 allergens giving you the option to choose what you wish to avoid. Once the items are selected, you will see the items that do contain your allergens and that do not contain your allergens.

It’s not easy to find the phone number to your local Blaze Pizza. Once you find your location on the website, click that location on the map view to get the phone number, address, and hours of operation.

name: Denny's
overviewText:
Most managers at Denny's that were contacted by Picknic were familiar with critical dietary restrictions and understand general procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions; however, there were some locations that lacked adequate knowledge regarding celiac disease and the risks of cross-contact with gluten in their kitchens.

There are three separate grill spaces. One cooks fish and chicken, the second cooks red meats and the third grill cooks pancakes, French toast and eggs. Dairy (butter) is used on all grills. The managers contacted by Picknic could not ensure that their grills were completely free of allergens. A few locations were willing to utilize new utensils, clean the grill and/or use pans to prepare foods for those with critical dietary restrictions, but it must be requested by the customer.

There are three fryers used. One fries fish and chicken and has cross-contact with fish, wheat, and egg. The second cooks breaded items like onion rings and has cross-contact with wheat and egg. The third fries cheese sticks and has cross-contact with dairy, wheat, and egg.

Denny’s has an informative allergen menu that designates if an item contains or may contain an allergen. There is also cross-contact information on the allergen menu and indicates if the item is processed in a facility or on equipment with an allergen. There is a further breakdown of information about tree nuts (almonds, coconut, hazelnut) and fish (anchovies, cod/pollock/white fish, salmon).

In summary, they have a wide menu, willingness to accommodate dietary restrictions, and an online allergen guide. However, their knowledge of critical dietary restrictions varied between locations and the restaurant chain does not have consistent procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions in the restaurants.

name: Chipotle Mexican Grill
overviewText:
Chipotle stands out for having a menu that is free of several top allergens. No peanuts, tree nuts, sesame, shellfish, or fish are used as food ingredients. Eggs are only an ingredient at locations that serve breakfast and only one menu item contains soy. Their allergen and special diets menu is very easy to use and understand and has excellent notes for added detail about ingredients. In addition to the top 8 allergens and gluten, Chipotle provides information for mustard and sulfites, as well as for those following a vegetarian, vegan, whole30, keto, or paleo diet.

Chipotle is happy to accomodate guests with critical dietary restrictions and looks to the customer for direction on any special handling they would like for their order. Upon request, gloves are changed and hands are washed. Unopened bins or unused product from the back can be used upon request for any guests concerned about cross-contact. You may request one staff member make your order, instead of passing it down the line. All items on the line have dedicated spoons/utensils so that cross-contact risk is reduced. The order is prepared right in front of you so you know everything that goes into it and can feel comfortable with the process. All locations are owned by the corporation so training, process, and ingredients are consistent. One negative is that there is no place to enter critical dietary restriction information when ordering online or through their app. Guests need to either call the location or visit in-person to communicate any critical dietary restriction needs.

overviewText: Though Applebee's provides an allergen menu, staff (including management) at locations we surveyed did not know the menu and potential sources of cross-contact well enough to guide guests. However, because of the lack of peanuts on their menu, Applebee's is a Picknic Pick for peanut-free.

name: Olive Garden Italian Kitchen
overviewText: Olive Garden impresses with transparent information about its menu items and operations that will allow those with critical dietary restrictions to make informed choices. Olive Garden’s website offers information for those avoiding the top 8 allergens, gluten, sesame, and sulfites. Their allergen guide also includes information on preparation methods and possible cross-contact. A menu detailing vegetarian and vegan options is also available on their website. In Picknic surveys, managers were knowledgeable about ingredients and procedures and were happy to accomodate guests with critical dietary restrictions.

name: Red Robin Gourmet Burgers and Brews
overviewText:

The output shows what items do not contain your restricted ingredients and highlights where cross-contact is possible. It also tells you how to modify certain menu items to meet your needs. The company provides further transparency on the FAQ section of their website, where additional information about cross-contact, staff training, and standard critical dietary restriction procedures is outlined. 

Managers surveyed were knowledgeable about critical dietary restrictions and their answers about their critical dietary restriction process were consistent with what was outlined on the corporate website. Red Robin is rated as a Picknic Pick for all of the top 8 allergens, gluten-free, and vegan critical dietary restrictions due the chain's high level of transparency on ingredients and cross-contact, staff training, and the policies in place to safely handle critical dietary restriction orders.

Although there are menu items that are free of peanuts, tree nuts, dairy, and soy, there is an elevated risk risk of cross-contact for these ingredients due to shared blenders.

name: Red Robin Gourmet Burgers and Brews
overviewText:
Red Robin provides an interactive allergen menu that includes the top 8 allergens, gluten-free, and vegan options. This menu allows the user to filter by critical dietary restriction. The output shows what items do not contain your restricted ingredients and highlights where cross-contact is possible. It also tells you how to modify certain menu items to meet your needs. The company provides further transparency on the FAQ section of their website, where additional information about cross-contact, staff training, and standard critical dietary restriction procedures is outlined. 

Managers surveyed were knowledgeable about critical dietary restrictions and their answers about their critical dietary restriction process were consistent with what was outlined on the corporate website. Red Robin is rated as a Picknic Pick for all of the top 8 allergens, gluten-free, and vegan critical dietary restrictions due the chain's high level of transparency on ingredients and cross-contact, staff training, and the policies in place to safely handle critical dietary restriction orders.

name: Noodles & Company
overviewText: Noodles & Company is a Picknic Pick for peanut-free, tree nut-free, fish-free, shellfish-free, and vegetarian. While the restaurant offers several gluten-free, dairy-free, and soy-free options and takes steps to keep these items separate, there is an elevated risk of cross-contact due to the high number of dishes in the restaurant that utilize these ingredients. Not all managers surveyed were familiar with Celiac Disease. However, all were aware of the importance of avoiding cross-contact for critical dietary restriction orders and all were happy to work to accommodate critical dietary restriction orders.

name: Chipotle Mexican Grill
overviewText:
Chipotle stands out for having a menu that is free of several top allergens. No peanuts, tree nuts, sesame, shellfish, or fish are used as food ingredients. Eggs are only an ingredient at locations that serve breakfast and only one menu item contains soy. Their allergen and special diets menu is very easy to use and understand and has excellent notes for added detail about ingredients. In addition to the top 8 allergens and gluten, Chipotle provides information for mustard and sulfites, as well as for those following a vegetarian, vegan, whole30, keto, or paleo diet.

Chipotle is happy to accomodate guests with critical dietary restrictions and looks to the customer for direction on any special handling they would like for their order. Upon request, gloves are changed and hands are washed. Unopened bins or unused product from the back can be used upon request for any guests concerned about cross-contact. You may request one staff member make your order, instead of passing it down the line. All items on the line have dedicated spoons/utensils so that cross-contact risk is reduced. The order is prepared right in front of you so you know everything that goes into it and can feel comfortable with the process. All locations are owned by the corporation so training, process, and ingredients are consistent. One negative is that there is no place to enter critical dietary restriction information when ordering online or through their app. Guests need to either call the location or visit in-person to communicate any critical dietary restriction needs.

name: Jamba Juice
overviewText:
Jamba Juice's online menu lists the ingredients used in each of their menu items and make special note of certain allergens present in their food, including dairy, soy, tree nuts (almond and coconut), wheat, and egg. The smoothies and juices at Jamba Juice allow for some modifications, if necessary, to accomodate for critical dietary restrictions.

The staff reviewed by Picknic gave consistent responses regarding their procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions and happily answered any questions regarding their menu items and the allergens at their location.

Picknic believes Jamba Juice is a good option for those with gluten, egg, and wheat critical dietary restrictions because there are few or no blended menu items that contain these allergens. The foods offered that contain wheat, gluten, and egg are specific to their breakfast items, flatbreads, and baked goods which are manufactured and individually packaged outside of the restaurant, stored in a separate refrigerator from their smoothie and juice ingredients, and cooked in an oven that is typically in a separate area from the blenders. Jamba Juice stores do not carry any fish or shellfish products.

Although there are menu items that are free of peanuts, tree nuts, dairy, and soy, there is an elevated risk risk of cross-contact for these ingredients due to shared blenders.

name: Chick-fil-A
overviewText:
Chick-Fil-A has a comprehensive allergen menu, the ability to print a list of all ingredients in an item for guests, and an excellent level of management training/customer service. Additionally, their willingness to change gloves, use fresh utensils, and make other accommodations is an outlier in the fast food industry.

That being said, it is possible that some locations will fall short of the general Chik-Fil-A standard. For orders that require special handling, we recommend placing your order in-store so that you can speak directly to an employee.

name: Starbucks
overviewText:
Starbucks provides abundant information about ingredients for all of their products. They are also clear on their website that they cannot guarantee that there will not be cross-contact of any allergen in their drinks and food. Each manager we surveyed echoed this and explained that shared equipment is used to prepare all their items. The managers expressed a willingness to instruct their staff to wash their hands, wash the pitchers, and use clean utensils when preparing a critical dietary restriction order.

Managers did tell us that ordering an iced drink has less of a chance for cross-contact since all components are poured directly into the cup.

name: Cold Stone Creamery
categories: Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Cupcakes, Custom Cakes
overviewText:
Cold Stone Creamery has a willingness to accommodate critical dietary restriction orders. They have standardized procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions. Locations reviewed by Picknic offered to scoop from fresh, unused ice cream tubs in the back of the house using fresh utensils for all critical dietary restrictions. This is a corporate policy and was upheld for all reviewed locations. Additionally, the staff will use clean cambro bins in the back to mix any ice cream orders for critical dietary restrictions to reduce the risk of cross-contact.

The set up of ice cream, toppings/add-ins, and cones can vary by location. Ice cream and sorbets are in individual bins and generally set up side by side in two rows. The order of the toppings can vary depending on the location. Some stores may put cookie/brownie toppings, tree nuts, and peanuts in the middle, and others may put them off to the side. Toppings are stored in individual covered containers and have their own scoop. The topping station is next to the ice cream station where there are cones and waffle cups above the toppings.

Ice creams, sorbets, and mix-ins are produced off-site. Picknic was unable to obtain information about Cold Stone Creamery's manufacturing process, so cross-contact in manufacturing may be possible.

name: Starbucks
overviewText:
Starbucks provides abundant information about ingredients for all of their products. They are also clear on their website that they cannot guarantee that there will not be cross-contact of any allergen in their drinks and food. Each manager we surveyed echoed this and explained that shared equipment is used to prepare all their items. The managers expressed a willingness to instruct their staff to wash their hands, wash the pitchers, and use clean utensils when preparing a critical dietary restriction order.

Managers did tell us that ordering an iced drink has less of a chance for cross-contact since all components are poured directly into the cup.

name: Blaze Fast-Fire’d Pizza
overviewText:
Blaze Pizza offers different pizzas to cater to people with different critical dietary restrictions. There are a few choices for dough ranging from wheat, gluten-free, cauliflower and keto. Blaze uses Daiya dairy-free cheese, offers a vegan chorizo topping, and has a large variety of meats and vegetable toppings. Regardless of your critical dietary restriction, building your own pizza is a good choice.

All pizzas are cooked in the same oven, however when we asked if there is a special place in the oven for critical dietary restriction pizzas we received different answers. Some said they use the far side of the oven for critical dietary restrictions, others surveyed said all pizzas go in the oven in no particular place.

Blaze Pizza has a Special Diets Wizard (allergen menu) online powered by nutritionix and lists 24 allergens giving you the option to choose what you wish to avoid. Once the items are selected, you will see the items that do contain your allergens and that do not contain your allergens.

It’s not easy to find the phone number to your local Blaze Pizza. Once you find your location on the website, click that location on the map view to get the phone number, address, and hours of operation.

name: Denny's
overviewText:
Most managers at Denny's that were contacted by Picknic were familiar with critical dietary restrictions and understand general procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions; however, there were some locations that lacked adequate knowledge regarding celiac disease and the risks of cross-contact with gluten in their kitchens.

There are three separate grill spaces. One cooks fish and chicken, the second cooks red meats and the third grill cooks pancakes, French toast and eggs. Dairy (butter) is used on all grills. The managers contacted by Picknic could not ensure that their grills were completely free of allergens. A few locations were willing to utilize new utensils, clean the grill and/or use pans to prepare foods for those with critical dietary restrictions, but it must be requested by the customer.

There are three fryers used. One fries fish and chicken and has cross-contact with fish, wheat, and egg. The second cooks breaded items like onion rings and has cross-contact with wheat and egg. The third fries cheese sticks and has cross-contact with dairy, wheat, and egg.

Denny’s has an informative allergen menu that designates if an item contains or may contain an allergen. There is also cross-contact information on the allergen menu and indicates if the item is processed in a facility or on equipment with an allergen. There is a further breakdown of information about tree nuts (almonds, coconut, hazelnut) and fish (anchovies, cod/pollock/white fish, salmon).

In summary, they have a wide menu, willingness to accommodate dietary restrictions, and an online allergen guide. However, their knowledge of critical dietary restrictions varied between locations and the restaurant chain does not have consistent procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions in the restaurants.

name: Domino's
overviewText:
Domino's has an online allergen guide posted for those with critical dietary restrictions to help customers navigate the menu.

The locations reviewed by Picknic were consistent in their procedures for handling critical dietary restrictions and were fairly knowledgeable of a variety of food allergies. They strive to be as accommodating as possible but their toppings bar, which contains meat, dairy, and fish products, is used for all pizzas and can be a risk for cross-contact for customers with those critical dietary restrictions. The staff change their gloves and prepares the pizzas on individual screens to reduce these risks but they cannot guarantee their foods are 100% free of those allergens. Additionally, they do not have separate ovens for different allergens so those with a gluten critical dietary restriction should be aware that their gluten-free pizza may come into contact with gluten-containing items in the oven or on the toppings bar. Some restaurants use stickers to identify gluten-free pizzas that they place on their boxes.

Overall, Domino's has standardized procedures and a good understanding of critical dietary restrictions.

name: Baskin-Robbins
categories: Coffee & Tea, Ice Cream & Frozen Yogurt, Donuts
overviewText:
All ice cream flavors are manufactured in the same facility. If you are comfortable with that, Baskin-Robbins should be a good option for you. Just be sure to ask the staff to wash their hands and get your ice cream from a fresh bin with fresh utensils. Otherwise, cross-contact is highly likely since the scoops used for ice cream and the wells for the scoops are shared. Toppings (including peanuts and tree nuts) are typically stored close together on the line, so there is an elevated risk of cross-contact between toppings.

The waffle cones offered are prepared in-house every day, whereas the sugar and cake cones are shipped from a factory. The waffle cones contain multiple allergens, including gluten, wheat, soy, eggs, and milk. The waffle irons are located in a separate area from the ice cream tubs and are produced in the morning to reduce risk of cross-contact.

Their online menu provides an easy-to-use filter to help customers navigate the menu according to their dietary restrictions or preferences, but not every flavor listed online is offered at every location.

The managers contacted by Picknic showed little knowledge regarding food allergies so you will need to be your own advocate. The procedures for accommodating critical dietary restrictions were not standardized across the reviewed facilities. There were discrepancies in the understanding of company policies and procedures; some locations did not require their employees to wear gloves when scooping ice cream, whereas other locations did require gloves.

name: Chili's Grill and Bar
overviewText:
Chili's extensive menu allows for many people with critical dietary restrictions to find food options suitable for them. For those with allergies, the staff is willing to accommodate as best they can by omitting ingredients accordingly and using fresh utensils when preparing the food.

It is important to inform your server of your food allergy immediately or make note of the allergy when ordering online. Some locations offer the option to have the critical dietary restriction-friendly meal brought to table on a separate tray from other prepared foods. Managers of the restaurants reviewed by Picknic highlighted the routine hand washing and changing of gloves by the kitchen staff, especially when preparing meals for critical dietary restrictions. The managers are trained on how to handle food allergies.

Each establishment is provided with resources for both staff and customers to determine what foods can be made or adjusted to fit critical dietary restrictions. As a whole, Chili's managers contacted by Picknic were quick to respond to questions and offer helpful information regarding their procedures and offer ways they could accomodate for a variety of food allergies. However, understanding of food allergies was occasionally inconsistent among the managers we surveyed.

Chili’s has a complex Allergen/Vegetarian/Vegan Matrix which designates cross-contact and the Top 8 Allergens in every item in addition to those dishes which are vegetarian and Vegan.

All of their fried foods are made in the same fryer so there are cross-contact risks for all food allergies with their fried menu items. All fish and shellfish food items are cooked in designated pans to reduce the risk of cross-contact with other food items. The fryer oil used varied amongst the restaurants contacted by Picknic but most of the locations used either soybean oil or vegetable oil (most likely soybean oil). The oil used on the flat top grills contained soy at most locations so it is important for customers with a soy allergy to discuss their allergy with a manager before ordering.

name: Del Taco
overviewText: Their dietary restriction menu contains information for the top 8 allergens, gluten, and vegan/vegetarian, and they have certainly given thought to serving those with vegetarian and vegan diets. Some locations reviewed by Picknic were more knowledgeable of critical dietary restrictions and willing to accomodate than others, but all locations offered to use fresh utensils and change gloves before preparing food for a critical dietary restriction.

name: Chuck E. Cheese
overviewText: Chuck-E-Cheese offers an allergen menu with the top 8 allergens plus gluten as well as additional information in the food allergy FAQs on their webpage. In our surveys, we found inconsistent levels of knowledge and training regarding critical dietary restrictions. Some managers were well-trained and appeared to have a consistent process for handling critical dietary restriction orders while others did not. Pizzas are assembled in the kitchen and cooked on trays that go through a conveyor-type oven. All other food items are cooked on trays that go through the same conveyor oven. Since all food items are cooked separately on trays it presents a reduced risk of cross-contact from shared cooking surfaces. Cross-contact is possible in the preparation spaces, particularly with wheat, gluten, dairy or soy.

name: Bubba Gump Shrimp Company
overviewText:
Overall, Bubba Gump Shrimp Company's management was knowledgeable of critical dietary restrictions and the allergens on the menu. They are willing to modify items as much as possible to meet the requests of their guests.

Parts of the grill are dedicated for allergies. The surface can be re-cleaned if there are doubts that it is free of an allergen, but items can be cooked in a fresh pan as well.

There are separate fryers for shrimp, chicken, and fries, but this is for operational purposes, not allergies. For example, it isn't a company policy that no other items go into the fryer for fries, so the fryer for fries may be used for other items in a pinch. For those with gluten, wheat, shellfish, fish, egg, soy, dairy, and tree nut (coconut) critical dietary restrictions, the managers we spoke with highly recommends avoiding all fried items. However, some locations offered to pan fry menu items using fresh pans in order to accomodate a critical dietary restriction.

name: P.F. Chang’s
overviewText:
P.F. Chang's made a commitment to serve guests with critical dietary restrictions such as celiac disease and food allergies long before it was common. They have years of experience and a culture that takes critical dietary restrictions seriously. They will work with you on almost any dietary restriction, and the fact that each dish is made to order in its own wok means that they don't have to make many changes to their process to avoid cross-contact.

Their online allergen menu lists the top 8 allergens, gluten, sulfites, sesame, corn, mushrooms, legumes, and onions.

name: California Pizza Kitchen
overviewText:
California Pizza Kitchen seems committed to serving people with critical dietary restrictions such as celiac disease and food allergies.

There is an elevated risk of cross-contact with many allergens due to the nature of how the prep stations are set up. The only menu items that CPK will guarantee to not have cross-contact are their certified gluten-free items. For these items, they guarantee there is not cross-contact with gluten.

Vegetarians and vegans will delight in reading the CPK Vegetarian and Vegan Menu Guide. This guide clearly outlines all the foods that are either naturally vegetarian or vegan or can be modified to become vegetarian or vegan.
